doc.after: A Gabrielino settlement in the area was called iyÃ¡angáº (written Yang-na by the Spanish), which has been translated as "poison oak place".[16][17] Yang-na has also been translated as "the valley of smoke."[71][72] Owing to geography, heavy reliance on automobiles, and the Los Angeles/Long Beach port complex, Los Angeles suffers from air pollution in the form of smog. The Los Angeles Basin and the San Fernando Valley are susceptible to atmospheric inversion, which holds in the exhausts from road vehicles, airplanes, locomotives, shipping, manufacturing, and other sources.[73]
